messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learning Barrier Certificates: Towards Safe Reinforcement Learning with Zero Training-time Violations

Paper Abstract: Abstract Training-time safety violations have been a major concern when we deploy reinforcement learning algorithms in the real world. This paper explores the possibility of safe RL algorithms with zero training-time safety violations in the challenging setting where we are only given a safe but trivial-reward initial policy without any prior knowledge of the dynamics model and additional offline data. We propose an algorithm, Co-trained Barrier Certificate for Safe RL (CRABS),which iteratively learns barrier certificates, dynamics models, and policies. The barrier certificates, learned via adversarial training, ensure the policy’s safety assuming calibrated learned dynamics model. We also add a regularization term to encourage larger certified regions to enable better exploration. Empirical simulations show that zero safety violations are already challenging for a suite of simple environments with only 2-4 dimensional state space, especially if high-reward policies have to visit regions near the safety boundary. Prior methods require hundreds of violations to achieve decent rewards on these tasks, whereas our proposed algorithms incur zero violations. 111The source code of this work is available at https://github.com/roosephu/crabs.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Constrained policy optimization",
        "Solving rubik’s cube with a robot hand",
        "Safe reinforcement learning via shielding",
        "Control barrier functions: Theory and applications",
        "Neurosymbolic reinforcement learning with formally verified exploration",
        "Safe model-based reinforcement learning with stability guarantees",
        "Conservative safety critics for exploration",
        "Openai gym",
        "Foundations of mathematical economics",
        "End-to-end safe reinforcement learning through barrier functions for safety-critical continuous control tasks",
        "A lyapunov-based approach to safe reinforcement learning",
        "Lyapunov-based safe policy optimization for continuous control",
        "Deep reinforcement learning in a handful of trials using probabilistic dynamics models",
        "Safe exploration in continuous action spaces",
        "On the expressivity of neural networks for deep reinforcement learning",
        "Enforcing robust control guarantees within neural network policies",
        "Leave no trace: Learning to reset for safe and autonomous reinforcement learning",
        "Addressing function approximation error in actor-critic methods",
        "Soft actor-critic algorithms and applications",
        "When to trust your model: Model-based policy optimization",
        "Safe reinforcement learning via probabilistic shields",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "Algorithmic framework for model-based deep reinforcement learning with theoretical guarantees",
        "Human-level control through deep reinforcement learning",
        "Exponential control barrier functions for enforcing high relative-degree safety-critical constraints",
        "Barrier-certified adaptive reinforcement learning with applications to brushbot navigation",
        "Pytorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library",
        "Safety verification of hybrid systems using barrier certificates",
        "On the necessity of barrier certificates",
        "Searching for activation functions",
        "The lyapunov neural network: Adaptive stability certification for safe learning of dynamical systems",
        "Provably safe pac-mdp exploration using analogies",
        "Trust region policy optimization",
        "Lyapunov barrier policy optimization",
        "Mastering the game of go without human knowledge",
        "Learning to be safe: Deep rl with a safety critic",
        "Responsive safety in reinforcement learning by pid lagrangian methods",
        "Episodic learning with control lyapunov functions for uncertain robotic systems",
        "Reward constrained policy optimization",
        "Recovery rl: Safe reinforcement learning with learned recovery zones",
        "Mujoco: A physics engine for model-based control",
        "Safe reinforcement learning via curriculum induction",
        "Accelerating safe reinforcement learning with constraint-mismatched policies",
        "Mopo: Model-based offline policy optimization",
        "Safe continuous control with constrained model-based policy optimization",
        "Safety-critical model predictive control with discrete-time control barrier function",
        "Individual calibration with randomized forecasting"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learning Barrier Certificates: Towards Safe Reinforcement Learning with Zero Training-time Violations, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
